name: Innocence Project
mission: By entering your email address, you agree to receive emails from the Innocence Project. By entering your phone number, you agree to receive recurring automated promotional and personalized marketing text messages (e.g. cart reminders) from The Innocence Project at the cell number used when signing up. Consent is not a condition of any purchase. Reply HELP for help and STOP to cancel. Msg frequency varies. Msg & data rates may apply. View Terms & Privacy.
theoryOfChange: The Innocence Project has a documented strategic framework, particularly outlined in their 'Transforming Systems' and 'Our Impact: By the Numbers' sections on their website. Their approach involves strategic litigation, policy reform, and education to address systemic flaws in the criminal legal system and prevent wrongful convictions. They work to improve access to post-conviction courts, strengthen police and prosecutorial accountability, advocate for compensation for wrongly convicted individuals, and reform practices that contribute to misidentifications, unreliable informant testimony, coerced guilty pleas, and false confessions. Their annual reports also detail their strategic goals, policy wins, and the impact of their efforts.

evaluationSources: New research on death investigations and forensic methods

dimension_explanations.alignment: As a Sadaqah-eligible organization, it offers a pathway for general charitable giving toward justice and advocacy [7]. However, the alignment score is medium-low due to its specialized focus on the U.S. legal system rather than traditional humanitarian relief [1][2].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization achieves systemic change through litigation and policy reform, reporting a total revenue of $32,455,846 to support its mission [1][2]. While it maintains a program expense ratio of 74.6%, the complex nature of legal exonerations results in a high cost per beneficiary [1][5].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Innocence Project works to exonerate the wrongly convicted and reform the criminal justice system through DNA testing and policy advocacy.

baseline_narrative.summary: The Innocence Project, Inc. is a national nonprofit dedicated to freeing innocent individuals and preventing future wrongful convictions [2]. The organization operates through core programs including post-conviction litigation and systemic policy reform to address the root causes of judicial error [3][4].

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization provides <cite id="4">verified counts of exonerations</cite> and successful legislative passages.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The organization uses DNA litigation to prove innocence, which then provides the empirical evidence needed to lobby for policy changes that prevent future errors.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: In legal advocacy, evidence of success is measured by court victories and policy changes.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the organization has high reserves, the <cite id="2">revenue CAGR of -9.8%</cite> suggests a need for sustained donor support to maintain growth.

strengths.detail: The organization holds a <cite id="3">perfect 100.0/100 from Charity Navigator</cite> for accountability and finance.
The charity maintains a <cite id="2">program expense ratio of 74.6%</cite>, ensuring the vast majority of funds support legal and policy work.
Since its founding, the project has reviewed thousands of cases, including <cite id="7">2,400 intake letters in a single year</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: The Innocence Project's primary strength lies in its dual-track approach of individual litigation and systemic advocacy. While many legal aid groups focus solely on casework, the Innocence Project uses its <cite id="4">verified exoneration outcomes</cite> to drive legislative change. Their financial health is bolstered by <cite id="2">$105.8 million in total assets</cite>, providing a massive safety net for complex litigation. Furthermore, the organization demonstrates high transparency with <cite id="3">100% independent board members</cite> and a clear <cite id="6">documented theory of change</cite> focused on systemic justice reform.
rich_narrative.summary: The Innocence Project is a national nonprofit organization dedicated to exonerating wrongly convicted individuals through DNA testing and reforming the criminal justice system to prevent future injustice. Founded in <cite id="1">1992</cite>, the organization has grown into a leading legal and policy institution that addresses the root causes of judicial error. In the 2023 fiscal year, the organization reported <cite id="2">total revenue of $32,455,846</cite>, primarily driven by <cite id="2">$26.6 million in public contributions</cite>. The organization maintains a highly efficient financial model, spending only <cite id="3">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite> of funding. Their work is divided into five core pillars: post-conviction litigation, policy reform, strategic litigation, data science, and social work support. By <cite id="4">2019</cite>, the organization had achieved <cite id="4">220 exonerations</cite>, a figure that grew from <cite id="5">200 people exonerated</cite> just two years prior. Beyond individual legal cases, the Innocence Project leverages its findings to advocate for <cite id="6">systemic policy reform</cite>, targeting issues such as eyewitness misidentification and unreliable forensic science. The organization is exceptionally stable, holding <cite id="3">41.7 months of working capital</cite> in reserve, ensuring that long-term legal battles—which can span decades—are fully funded to completion.
